anchor.surface_text: Section 9 of the Act on which the entire argument rests, reads- Disqualification for Government contracts. A person shall be disqualified, if, and for so long as, there subsists a contract entered into by him in the course of his trade or business with the appropriate Government for the supply of goods to, or for the execution of any works undertaken by, that Government.

concepts.interpretation: Applies to personal contracts in course of trade/business, not company's via chairman

arguments.claim: Speakers at public meeting on June 13, 1968 made false statements about petitioner's misappropriation of workers' funds, believed to be false or not believed true, with returned candidate's consent, constituting corrupt practice under s.123(4)

anchor.surface_text: It was averred in that sub-para that at a public meeting held at about 8, P.M. on June 13, 1968, at Jawahar Chowk at which the returned candidate was present, Abdul Rehman Talib of Dewas, Kanhaiyasingh Thakur of Dewas, Kr. Virendrasingh, Deputy Minister of Labour, Government of Madhya Pradesh and Khasherao. Ghorpade of Dewas, in the course of their speeches, made statements relating to the personal character and conduct of the petitioner appellant which were false and which the speakers and the returned candidate either believed to be false or did not believe to be true and those statements were reasonably calculated to prejudice the petitioner appellants prospects of election.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ning of June 13, 1968 at about 8-00 P.M. an election meeting was actually held in Jawahar Chowk, Dewas, and it was called in support of the respondent

arguments.claim: Statements in Ranchandi weekly on June 16, 1968 calling petitioner misappropriator and corrupt constitute corrupt practice under s.123(4)

anchor.surface_text: The controversy covered by this issue which still survives is confined to the statements alleged to have been published in the issue of the weekly Ranchandi dated June 16, 1968. From that issue the following extracts published in connection with the election in question were relied upon by the appellant in support of the allegations of the corrupt practice - Voters beware of Joshi misappropriator of the workers subscription.

arguments.claim: Chairman of company not entering personal contract in trade/business under s.9; company distinct entity

anchor.surface_text: A Company registered under the Indian Companies Act, it is settled beyond dispute, is a separate entity distinct from its shareholders. The Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Company while functioning as such cannot be said to be engaged in his trade or business as contemplated by S. 9A of the Act.

arguments.claim: Order framing charge and criminal complaint inadmissible in election petition
arguments.court_reasoning: No provision renders inadmissible; relevant under Evidence Act ss.7,8,11(2)

arguments.claim: Lal Singh's statement in criminal court inadmissible
arguments.court_reasoning: Relevant under Evidence Act ss.7,8,11(2); elicited by petitioner

arguments.claim: Heavy burden on petitioner to prove falsity and lack of bona fides under s.123(4)

anchor.surface_text: there is a very heavy burden on the petitioner appellant to prove the most vital ingredients prescribed in s. 123 4 of the Act, namely, that the impugned statement of fact is not only false, but in addition that the respondent returned candidate and his agents publishing the impugned statements either believed the same to be false or did not believe them to be true

arguments.claim: Bona fide statements protected even if untrue under s.123(4)

anchor.surface_text: As held in Sheo palsingh v. Rampratap A.I.R. 1965 S. C. 677 even if the statement is false the candidate -making it is protected unless he makes it believing it to be false not believing it to be true i.e., to say statements which are not true but made bona fide are also outside the ambit of the provisions of section 123 4 of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ems so called out from the extracts  Ex. P. 1 and P. 2  have number been shown to be an additional expenditure and number companyered by the election

holdings.text: The returned candidate is not disqualified under section 9A of the Representation of the People Act as the contract for supply of electricity was by the company, which is a separate legal entity, and not entered into by him personally in the course of his trade or business.

anchor.surface_text: A Company registered under the Indian Companies Act, it is settled beyond dispute, is a separate entity distinct from its shareholders. The Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Company while functioning as such cannot be said to be engaged in his trade or business as contemplated by S. 9A of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 9A applies only to personal contracts in course of trade/business; company is distinct entity (settled law); chairmanship does not impute personal contract.

holdings.text: There is no corrupt practice under section 123(4) of the Representation of the People Act as the petitioner failed to prove the impugned statements were false and either believed false or not believed true by the returned candidate or agents; pending criminal complaint provides bona fide basis.

anchor.surface_text: We are in full agreement with the approach and the final conclusion of the High Court. The essential basic facts seems to us to be incontrovertible, and if that be so, then clearly there is a very heavy burden on the petitioner appellant to prove the most vital ingredients prescribed in s. 123 4  of the Act, namely, that the impugned statement of fact is not only false, but in addition that the respondent returned candidate and his agents publishing the impugned statements either believed the same to be false or did not believe them to be true

holdings.reasoning_summary: Full agreement with High Court; heavy burden on petitioner not discharged; no material proving lack of bona fides; 1965 criminal complaint (ss.403/406 IPC) pending during election provides reasonable basis for statements even if untrue (following Sheopal Singh precedent).

holdings.text: The order framing charge, criminal complaint, and Lal Singh's statement in criminal court are admissible in the election petition.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No legal provision bars admissibility; relevant under Evidence Act ss.7,8,11(2); statement elicited by petitioner in cross-examination.

holdings.text: There is no corrupt practice under section 123(6) read with section 77 and rule 90 as the petitioner failed to prove that petrol purchases worth Rs.2000 were entirely for election purposes.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Insufficient evidence linking entire petrol/oil to election; candidate owned multiple vehicles for household/agricultural use; High Court reasoning unexceptionable.

holdings.text: Statements made at the meeting are attributable to the returned candidate as made in his interest with probable approval, even assuming denial of consent.

anchor.surface_text: He also denied that the statement made by the speakers at the meeting had been made with his consent but in the circumstances of the case we would assume that he cannot disown those statements which were made in his interest and, therefore, they were in all probability made with his approval.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presence throughout accepted; cannot disown statements in his interest at his meeting.

holdings.text: Returned candidate was present throughout the meeting on June 13, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Though in the written statement the returned candidate denied that he had continued to be present at the meeting, the Court below held that he was present throughout and this finding in our view must be accepted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts High Court factual finding on evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Sheo palsingh v. Rampratap  A.I.R. 1965 S. C. 677  even if the statement is false the candidate -making it is protected unless he makes it believing it to be false number believing it to be true i.e., to say statements which are number true but made bona fide are also outside the ambit of the provisions of section 123 4  of the Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: Even if a statement is false, the candidate making it is protected unless believed to be false or not believed to be true; bona fide statements not true are outside s.123(4)
precedents.cited_holding: statements which are number true but made bona fide are also outside the ambit of the provisions of section 123(4) of the Act

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court order dismissing election petition upheld; all charges of corrupt practices (false statements, excess expenditure) and disqualification under s.9A rejected.
